taxon_name.authority: (Magill, Delgadillo & L. R. Stark) R. H. Zander

bio:treatment.discussion: Distinguishing features of Syntrichia chisosa include the 2-stratose laminae, strongly serrate abaxial surface of the costa, plane leaf margins, mucronate apex, and costate, foliose propagula. In the northern part of its range, the species frequently occurs with S. bartramii (see comments thereunder). Syntrichia chisosa also occurs with S. fragilis, and the two may be confused because of a superficially similar habit, color, and dry leaf stance, but S. chisosa can be distinguished with a handlens by non-fragile leaves, a fuzzy appearance of the back of the costa, and usually abundant propagula, and, under a compound microscope, by smaller, 2-stratose, and relatively obscure laminal cells.
